description: From Middle English habitude, from Middle French habitude, from Latin habitūdō (“condition, plight, habit, appearance”), from habeō (“I have, hold, keep”).

entries.meaning: (archaic) The essential character of one's being or existence; native or normal constitution; mental or moral constitution; bodily condition; native temperament.
examples: His real habitude gave life and grace To appertainings and to ornament.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Habitual disposition; normal or characteristic mode of behaviour, whether from habit or from nature
examples: An habitude of commanding his passions in order to his health.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Behaviour or manner of existence in relation to something else; relation; respect.
examples: Proportion ... signifies the habitude or relation of one quantity to another.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) In full habitude: fully, wholly, entirely; in all respects.
examples: Although I believe not the report in full habitude.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) habitual association; familiar relation; acquaintance; familiarity; intimacy; association; intercourse.
examples: The discourse of some with whom I have had some habitudes since my coming home.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) an associate; an acquaintance; someone with whom one is familiar.
examples: La Corneus and Sallyes were the only habitudes we had.
Which  […]  by long habitude, are thought rather vertue than vice among them.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, chemistry, in the plural) The various ways in which one substance reacts with another; chemical reaction.
examples: Most authors who have had occasion to describe naphthaline, have noticed its habitudes with sulphuric acid.
